STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 25, 2023
Renee Adorjan
Washtenaw County DHHS
22 Center St,
Ypsilanti, MI, 48198-5707
Re: License #: CP810201490
Dear Ms. Adorjan:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
10/5/2023. An Exit conference was held with the agency on 10/13/2021. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP810201490
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Renee Adorjan
Name of Agency: Washtenaw County DHHS
Agency Address: 22 Center St.
Ypsilanti, MI 48198-5707
Agency Telephone #: 734-481-8364
Original Issuance Date: 10/05/1994
License Status Regular
License Effective Date 11/5/2022
License Expiration Date 11/4/2024
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Supervise
Independent Living, Place children in foster
home
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 10/2/2023-10/6/2023
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 25 4
Homes pending licensure 3 3
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 2 2
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 1 1
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect
in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 0 0
Children receiving direct foster care case management (placement in foster homes,
parental home, relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 48 6
Children discharged from care during this period 24 5

Youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection 1 1
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A
Applicants denied for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A

Open child adoption cases N/A N/A

More than a year 15 7

2

B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
Licensed foster homes 25 3
Unlicensed relative homes 12 3
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 7
Relatives 3
Others (identify person interviewed by role) N/A
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household must have
training in and maintain a current certification in first aid
and cardiopulmonary resuscitation from the American
Heart Association or the American Red Cross, or other
institution approved by the department.
One of four open foster home records reviewed did not show documentation of a
current first aid and CPR certificate for the foster parent. The foster parent's
certificate expired 3/19/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation of all relevant parties,
including the child or infant, which includes an
explanation as to why the change is necessary.
In one of six open foster child records reviewed the record did not show
documentation of the child's preparation for placement related to two replacements
for this child on 11/9/2022 and 1/13/2023 respectively.
2

CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to
the time of the change in placement and the needs that
remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of five closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a)
and (b) as required by the rule at the time of the record's review for this case that
closed on 4/19/2023. The agency completed the document/documentation after the
fact on 10/3/2023.
Repeat Violation cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with a CAP
approved on 10/26/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into an
out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of the last
physical examination.
One of six open foster child records reviewed showed the child's initial medical
exam was due by 12/4/2022 and completed eight days late on 12/12/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
3

One of five initial service plans reviewed did not show documentation of (c) as
required by the rule.
Repeat Violation cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with a CAP
approved on 10/31/2022; and the 2021 Interim inspection, with a CAP
approved on 12/17/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be used
by the foster parents.
One of 13 updated service plans reviewed did not show documentation of the
behavior support plan to be used for the five-year-old.
Repeat Violation cited during the 2021 Interim inspection, with a CAP
approved on 12/17/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child's
placement at least once every month.
One six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of a March
2023 home visit with the child and caregiver.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.
In one of six open foster child records reviewed, where the child was placed
separately from their siblings, the record did not show documentation of a February
2023 sibling visit.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
4

(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(c) A summary of the services provided during care and
the needs that remain to be met.
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
One of one closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of(c) and (d) as required by the rule at the time of the youth's
reported 6/22/2023 case closure, or my review of the case on 10/2/2023. The
agency provided the document/documentation of such on 10/13/2023, dated for
10/3/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(a) Basic information about health, housing, counseling
and mental health services, and emergency resources.
One of one closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) as required by the rule at the time of the youth's reported
6/22/2023 case closure, or my review of the case on 10/2/2023. The agency
provided the document/documentation of such on 10/13/2023, dated for 10/3/2023.
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must
be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward Service
5

Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Semi-Annual Transition Meeting
Within 30 calendar days after the child’s 14th birthday
and every six months thereafter
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documenation of an FTM for the child’s 2/22/2023-
5/21/2023 or 5/22/2023-8/19/2023 respective updated service plan(USP).
An FTM was completed on 3/16/2023 and 6/28/2023 both not within the
required time frame.
• Two other records did not show documentation of a required semi-annual
transitional meeting for the respective child.
Repeat Violation cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with a CAP
approved on 10/31/2022; and the 2021 Interim inspection, with a CAP
approved on 12/17/2021.
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
Post Family Team Meeting:
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for the
following: • Completing the DHS-1105, Family Team
Meeting Report, checking it for accuracy, identifying
areas needing follow-up, and recording the outcome
data.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of a DHS-1105 for an FTM
indicated on 11/29/2022.
• A second record did not show documentation of a DHS-1105 for an FTM
indicated on 5/22/2023 and 8/28/2023.
Repeat Violation cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with a CAP
approved on 10/31/2022; and the 2021 Interim inspection, with a CAP
approved on 12/17/2021.
FOM 722-8D Treatment Plan.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
6

• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Eight of 18 service plans reviewed (related to three of six open foster child records
reviewed) did not show compliance:
• One child’s 5/10/2023-6/10/2023 treatment plan for the initial service plan
(ISP) was not signed by the caregiver and birth parent within the time frame
required by the standard. The agency provided documentation at the Exit
Conference on 10/13/2023 showing the caregiver signed the treatment plan
on 10/12/2023 and the birth parent signed it on 10/13/2023.
• A second child’s 8/22/2022-9/20/2022 treatment plan for the ISP and
treatment plans for the next three USPs were not signed by the caregiver or
birth parent(s).
• A third child’s 11/28/2022-2/21/2023 USP treatment plan, and the treatment
plan for the next two USPs were not signed by the caregiver and agency
staff within the time frame required by the standard. The agency provided
documentation at the Exit Conference on 10/13/2023 showing the caregiver
and foster care worker both signed all the indicated treatment plans on
10/11/2023; and the supervisor signed on 10/13/2023.
Repeat Violation cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with a CAP
approved on 10/31/2022; and the 2021 Interim inspection, cited under FOM
722-8C, with a CAP approved on 12/17/2021.
FOM 801-C Medical Passport.
Initial medical passport:
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the child's
placement date to the following.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s records did not show documentation that the caregiver was
provided a copy ot the child’s medical passport within two weeks of the
child’s placement.
7

• A second child’s record did not show documentation of an current medical
passport showing documentation of the child’s 5/30/2023 medical exam and
5/22/2023 dental exam.
• A third child’s record did not show documentation of an initial medical
passport for the child showing documentation of the child’s 5/31/2023
medical exam and 7/28/2023 dental exam.
Repeat Violation cited during the 2021 Interim inspection, cited under ISEP
6.49, with a CAP approved on 12/17/2021.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
R400.12324(1) Reevaluation
• The agency is apprised it shall clearly and consistently document any
reevaluation delays presented by the foster parents.
• The agency was further advised the foster home’s reevaluation must
consistently show documentation of both the foster parents’ strengths and area
of needed growth as indicated by the foster parents themselves, as well as what
is assessed by the worker.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Nothing this inspection
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan during this
reporting period. The corrective action plan related to the agency's 2022 Renewal
inspection where it received the following rule violations:
• R400.12324(8) Reevaluation.
• R400.12326(1)(f)(g) Borrowed home.
• R400.1237(4) Special evaluation.
• R400.12327(5)(d) Special evaluation.
8

• R400.12327(6)(c) Special evaluation.
• R400.12405(5)(a) &(b) Change of placement.
• R400.12413(1) (f)(i) Medical and dental care policy.
• R400.12418(2)(a) Development of service plans.
• R400.12419(1)(c) &(h) Initial service plans.
• ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS (Commitment 22).
• ISEP 6.33(5)(c) Assessment and Services Plans, Content (Commitment
69).
• FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
• FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans-Overview, Types, And Timeframes-
Supervisors Approval.
• FOM 722-8D Treatment plan. Agreement and signature.
• FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
• FOM 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and Developmental Needs of
children under Supervision of MDHHS.
Despite the repeat violations as indicated in this report, the agency made
significant progress with this corrective action plan. The agency provided proof of
training it indicated would occur. It showed samples of supervisor/worker monthly
case conference notes showing continued discussions and focus with workers on
service plans, family team meetings, trauma screenings, medicals and dentals and
needed treatment plan signatures. Proof of its efforts with the corrective action
plan were also provided by way of spreadsheets it used, copies of emails
illustrating reminders to workers on various required reports, employee
evaluations, service plans, and needed MISACWIS uploads. The agency also
provided samples of various staff meeting agendas showing discussions with staff
on medical passports, uploading documents, FTMs, immunization, DHS-69-
Action summaries, borrowed beds, special evaluations, social work contacts, HLO
(Health Liaison Officer) role/involvement, foster home/caregiver visits, the DCWL
(Division of Child Welfare Licensing) audit, foster care and licensing case audits,
etc. All tasks were demonstrative of the agency’s efforts towards complying with
licensing rules.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 10/2/2023. The report
showed the agency’s review of its 2022 noncompliance, and assessment of
barriers and key performance indicators; as well as other areas, as required by the
rule and assessment. No concerns were observed.
Financial Overview
Not applicable; this is a state agency.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to engaging with the chief administrator, the section manager, and
licensing supervisor, three foster care worker and one supervisor were
interviewed. The staff reported positive remarks about the agency; such as it
9

having very supportive management, an approachable director, a family-oriented
environment, and that there is constant team work, and compassionate coworkers
and supervisors. Areas of concern reported by staff centered on a need for more
resources to assist workers, a desire to have balance caseloads, whereby not just
the number of cases is counted, but also the degree of activities and
responsibilities on the case. Further concern centered on the fact that the county
has a new judge; and difficulties and concerns coming from that, and various court
rulings.
There were no youths interview this reporting; one was attempted.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A tour was completed, and no safety issues or area of concern were observed.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety Alerts this inspection.
RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
October 24, 2023
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 25, 2023
________________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Area Manager
10
